name: 4-(2,2,2-trimethylacetamido)pyridine
Reason: The basic unit, pyridine, has a melting point of around -42°C which serves as our starting point. The presence of an amide functional group (acetamido) usually raises the melting point due to the ability of the nitrogen to participate in hydrogen bonding: +70°C. The introduction of three methyl groups as part of a tertiary butyl structure (2,2,2-trimethyl) generally increases the melting point due to the increase in molecular size and van der Waals forces: +50°C each for the first two methyl groups and +20°C for the steric hindrance of the third one being less effective due to diminishing returns in hindrance and van der Waals forces. Even though each methyl group does not contribute equally, for predictive ease, a rounded average effect per methyl group is considered.
Test (Predicted reason):
- Basic unit, pyridine, has a melting point of 17 °C. 
- The amide group (C(=O)N) typically raises the melting point due to strong hydrogen bonding and resonance stabilization, which can be estimated at +80 °C. 
- The three methyl groups attached to the amide nitrogen will increase the molecular weight and steric hindrance, which can be estimated at +15 °C for each methyl group. 
- The overall molecular structure is complex and rigid, which can further increase the melting point, estimated at +10 °C. 
Therefore, the combined effects of these functional groups can be calculated as follows: 17 (pyridine) + 80 (amide) + 15 (first methyl) + 15 (second methyl) + 10 (rigidity) = 127 °C.
##Prediction: 127.0
